results.title: Free to be, you and me
results.creator_credit: Murakami-Wolf Productions, Marlo Thomas, Carole Hart and Bill Davis
results.brief_description: A special program designed for a more structural approach to exploration of personal development concepts. Includes an all star cast from stage and screen, presenting in live action, animation and puppetry two thematically designed units: Friendship and co-operation; Expectations and independence. Features Alan Alda, Harry Belafonte, Mel Brooks, Rita Coolidge, Billy the Wolfe, Roberta Flack, Michael Jackson, Kris Kristofferson, Bobby Morse, The New Seekers, Tom Smothers, Cecily Tyson, The Voices ofo East Harlem and Dionne Warwick.

results.title: Free radicals
results.brief_description:
A primitive kinetic dance of white lines and angles meticulously scratched onto black and white film over an 8 month period and then edited and retrospectively matched with an African field tape of the Bagirmi tribe. The title is a reference to modern physics, ‘free radicals’ being particles of energy. The original version was a major award winner at the Experimental Film Competition at the 1958 Brussels World Fair. This revised version was a reworking of the
original by Lye in 1979, with financial assistance from
the New Zealand Film Commission. He deleted approximately 1 min. from his first version, made in 1958.

results.title: Free fall
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Tom Daly, Colin Low and Arthur Lipsett
results.brief_description: Made of film trimmings assembled by Arthur Lipsett, this experimental film conveys a flow of intense psychological impressions representing a new form of filmed perception. Compressed into an intermittent sequence of visuals, sounds, voices and bursts of music, this film makes a wry comment on modern man and his world. It suggests a surrealist dream of mankind’s fall from grace into banality. (Awards: Montreal; San Francisco)

results.title: Free cinema
results.creator_credit: Graphic Production, Graphic Films, Leon Clore, Karel Reisz, Lindsay Anderson and John Fletcher
results.brief_description: ‘Free Cinema’ was not a movement so much as a group of young filmmakers (including Lindsay Anderson, Tony Richardson and Karel Reisz), reacting against the class bound British cinema by working outside the dictates of the industry, although not entirely without its support. The filmmakers use of lighter and more flexible camera equipment and faster film stock, combined with their portrayal of contemporary life, injected the British documentary tradition with a new life. While inevitably portraying working class life from a middle class perspective which was not always free from left-wing sentimentality, ‘Free Cinema’ filmmakers did turn their cameras on previously ignored (on film), areas of British life. ‘Every Day Except Christmas’ (Dir; Lindsay Anderson, 40 mins. 1957) is a lyrical, implicitly idealistic, portrayal of working class community at the Covent Garden Market. ‘We Are the Lambeth Boys’ (Dir; Karel Reisz, 50 mins. 1959) tries to get close to working class youth culture. ‘The Saturday Men’ (Dir; John Fletcher, 29 mins. 1959) is the portrait of a football club.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Graphic Production, Graphic Films, Leon Clore, Karel Reisz, Lindsay Anderson and John Fletcher

results.title: Free as the birds
results.brief_description: A schoolboy traps and cages four wild birds. When the teacher explains to his class the need to protect birds and to allow them freedom so that they can eat insects which would otherwise destroy the very food we eat, he has the courage to admit his guilt. The children go into the woods to return the birds to their natural home.

results.title: Free and enterprising
results.creator_credit: Geoffrey Barnes, Film Australia and Paul Humfress
results.brief_description: Illustrates the factors which are important for small business success and the importance of basic techniques in planning and control which are essential to the survival and growth of the enterprise.

results.title: Frederick
results.creator_credit: Connecticut Films, Giulio Gianini and Leo Lionni
results.brief_description: Based on the children’s book by Leo Lionni this film tells of four grey field mice who diligently gather food in preparation for winter, and a fifth - Frederick - who quietly sits and absorbs the joys of summer. When, in the winter, the mice have exhausted their food supply, Frederick is able to cheer his companions by recalling the visions and sensations of summer. Animated.

results.title: Freda Koblicks plastics workshop
results.brief_description: Freda Koblicks conducts plastics workshops and during these, discusses her ideas about working with plastics. These ideas concern not only techniques but also appreciation of dealing with the material.

results.title: Fred Winter
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “British Sporting Personalities”.
A film portrait of Fred Winter, one of Britain’s leading steeplechase jockeys. Fred started riding at the age of four; now in his thirties, his outstanding career has seen him winner of the Grand National, twice winner of the Champion Hurdle, and four times Champion Jockey. Sequences show him in action during races, at home with his wife and children in consultation with a trainer.
